prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the [CII] 158 micron line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will map the [CII] 158 micron line in SMMJ02399 with 0.4" beam, 20 km/s channel width.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have picked the resolution element of 2.35 km/s so that, in that we can achieve ~100 elements over the expected line width while also minimizing the data rate. This is chosen that that if there are small, and compact emission regions, we can image the [CII] line at higher than the 20 km/s channel widths used in estimating our requested line sensitivity. Additionally, the expected source integrated line flux is high enough (~200-sigma in a 20 km/s bin) that we expect we can spectrally resolve the line with the chosen spectral window resolution of ~2 km/s

As can be seen in figure 1 of our scientific justification, optical HST imaging shows that SMMJ02399 extends over ~3", based on Cycle-0 observations we expect that the [CII] line to be similarly extended. To ensure we will recover the full [CII] flux, and not resolve out the line as happened in Cycle-0, we have simulated observations of the [CII] line (the [NII] line model is shown in Figure 4, the results for the [CII] line are essentially identical) assuming it follows the flux distribution of the HST imaging, yet scaled to the expected ZEUS-1 line flux. Based on this simulation we expect to fully recover the [CII]. For angular resolution, we have chosen 0.4", which is sufficient to separate spatially separate SMMJ02399 four components, while also ensure a significant detection of the line can obtained in no more than 1 hour of total integration time. Our simulated image shows that 0.4" will provide excellent detail on the source morphology.

To determine our sensitivity we assume the [CII] flux is equal to our observed ZEUS-1 [OIII] line flux, reasonable based on nearby observations (e.g. Parkin et al. 2013, 2014, Hughes et al. 2015), and assumed a conservative case of a flat-topped line profile and that the line arise uniformly over the source, which is ~2.5" in diameter. In other words we take a line flux of 130 Jy km/s, divided by the line width of ~320 km/s, split into 39 ALMA beams ~0.4" in diameter to get an estimate peak flux-density for the line in each beam of 18.5 mJy per beam. For our sensitivity we require at least a 5-sigma detection of the line, corresponding to our requested RMS of 3.19 mJy. We have selected a channel width of 20 km/s, so that we can have at least 3 channels across our estimated linewidth, while keeping the requested total integration time to less than 60 minutes. Our achieved continuum sensitivity does not drive our time requests, however we expect to strongly detect the continuum regardless. Since we successfully detect the ~100 micron continuum from the L2SW and L1 components of the source in our Cycle-0, we instead base our single-to-noise continuum estimate on the undetected components, L2 and L1N. These were undetected down too the cycle-0 RMS of ~1mJy per 0.25" beam. As such we expect that there continuum to be no larger than 3.80 mJy per 0.4" beam of our Cycle-3 observations. Given our requested integration time for the line observations, we can expect to detect the L2 and L1N components at the 8.6-sigma level, if the continuum was just below our Cycle-0 detection limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the [NII] 122 micron line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will map the [NII] 122 micron line in SMMJ02399 with 0.4" beam, 50 km/s channel width.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have picked the resolution element of 1.81 km/s so that, in that we can achieve ~100 elements over the expected line width while also minimizing the data rate. This is chosen that that if there are small, and compact emission regions, we can image the [NII] line at higher than the 50 km/s channel widths used in estimating our requested line sensitivity. Additionally, the expected source integrated line flux is high enough (~200-sigma in a 50 km/s bin) that we expect we can spectrally resolve the line with the chosen spectral window resolution of ~2 km/s

As can be seen in figure 1 of our scientific justification, optical HST imaging shows that SMMJ02399 extends over ~3", based on Cycle-0 observations we expect that the [NII] line to be similarly extended. To ensure we will recover the full [NII] flux, and not resolve out the line as happened in Cycle-0, we have simulated observations of the [NII] line (show in Figure 4) assuming it follows the flux distribution of the HST imaging, yet scaled to the expected ZEUS-1 line flux. Based on this simulation we expect to fully recover the [NII]. For angular resolution, we have chosen 0.4", which is sufficient to separate spatially separate SMMJ02399 four components, while also ensure a significant detection of the line can obtained in no more than 1 hour of total integration time. Our simulated image shows that 0.4" will provide excellent detail on the source morphology.

To determine our sensitivity we have taken our observed ZEUS-1 line flux and assumed a conservative case of a flat-topped line profile and that the line arise uniformly over the source, which is ~2.5" in diameter. In other words we take a line flux of 130 Jy km/s, divided by the line width of 180 km/s, split into 39 ALMA beams ~0.4" in diameter to get an estimate peak flux-density for the line in each beam of 18.5 mJy per beam. For our sensitivity we require at least a 5-sigma detection of the line, corresponding to our requested RMS of 3.70 mJy. We have selected a channel width of 50 km/s, so that we can have at least 3 channels across our estimated linewidth, while keeping the requested total integration time to less than 60 minutes. Our achieved continuum sensitivity does not drive our time requests, however we expect to strongly detect the continuum regardless. Since we successfully detect the ~100 micron continuum from the L2SW and L1 components of the source in our Cycle-0, we instead base our single-to-noise continuum estimate on the undetected components, L2 and L1N. These were undetected down too the cycle-0 RMS of ~1mJy per 0.25" beam. As such we expect that there continuum to be no larger than 3.80 mJy per 0.4" beam of our Cycle-3 observations. Given our requested integration time for the line observations, we can expect to detect the L2 and L1N components at the 8.6-sigma level, if the continuum was just below our Cycle-0 detection limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping the [OIII] 88 micron line
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will map the [OIII] 88 micron line in SMMJ02399 with 0.4" beam, 50 km/s channel width.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have picked the resolution element of 2.63 km/s so that, in that we can achieve ~100 elements over the expected line width while also minimizing the data rate. This is chosen that that if there are small, and compact emission regions, we can image the [OIII] line at higher than the 20 km/s channel widths used in estimating our requested line sensitivity. Additionally, the expected source integrated line flux is high enough (~200-sigma in a 20 km/s bin) that we expect we can spectrally resolve the line with the chosen spectral window resolution of ~2 km/s

As can be seen in figure 1 of our scientific justification, optical HST imaging shows that SMMJ02399 extends over ~3", based on Cycle-0 observations we expect that the [OIII] line to be similarly extended. To ensure we will recover the full [OIII] flux, and not resolve out the line as happened in Cycle-0, we have simulated observations of the [OIII] line (the [NII] line model is shown in Figure 4, the results for the [OIII] line are essentially identical) assuming it follows the flux distribution of the HST imaging, yet scaled to the expected ZEUS-1 line flux. Based on this simulation we expect to fully recover the [OIII]. For angular resolution, we have chosen 0.4", which is sufficient to separate spatially separate SMMJ02399 four components, while also ensure a significant detection of the line can obtained in no more than 1 hour of total integration time. Our simulated image shows that 0.4" will provide excellent detail on the source morphology.

To determine our sensitivity take the ZEUS-1 [OIII] line flux and assumed a conservative case of a flat-topped line profile and that the line arise uniformly over the source, which is ~2.5" in diameter. In other words we take a line flux of 130 Jy km/s, divided by the line width of ~320 km/s, split into 39 ALMA beams ~0.4" in diameter to get an estimate peak flux-density for the line in each beam of 18.5 mJy per beam. For our sensitivity we require at least a 5-sigma detection of the line, corresponding to our requested RMS of 3.19 mJy. We have selected a channel width of 50 km/s, so that we can have at least 3 channels across our estimated linewidth, while keeping the requested total integration time to less than 60 minutes. Our achieved continuum sensitivity does not drive our time requests, however we expect to strongly detect the continuum regardless. Since we successfully detect the ~100 micron continuum from the L2SW and L1 components of the source in our Cycle-0, we instead base our single-to-noise continuum estimate on the undetected components, L2 and L1N. These were undetected down too the cycle-0 RMS of ~1 mJy per 0.25" beam. As such we expect that there continuum to be no larger than 3.80 mJy per 0.4" beam of our Cycle-3 observations. Given our requested integration time for the line observations, we can expect to detect the L2 and L1N components at the 8.6-sigma level, if the continuum was just below our Cycle-0 detection limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose using the ALMA 12-meter array in Cycle-3 to map the [CII] 158 m, [NII] 122 m and [OIII] m lines in the high-z merging system SMM J02399-0136. These observations are a unique opportunity to study the multiphase ISM of both an AGN and starburst in a high-z merger. Using our z(Redshift) and Early Universe Spectrometer (ZEUS-1) we made single dish detections of the [NII] and [OIII] lines in SMMJ02399. Based on this work we used ALMA in Cycle-0 to map the [NII] linesuccessfully detecting the line and 122 m continuum at ~0.25 scales. In Cycle-3 we will map the [CII], [OIII] and the [NII] lines at ~0.4 scales, the last letting us recover the missing flux of our Cycle-0 observations. Our observations will let us (1) perform the first resolved study of the lines at high-z, (2) map the dust continuum, and (3) create a complete picture of SMMJ02399s ionized, atomic, and molecular gas phases by combining our Cycle-3 observations with existing studies. We will enable a detailed investigation of the link between AGN, star formation, and mergers when the universe was only ~2 billion years old. Completing our Cycle-3 observations requires 4-hours of total observing time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
Submillimeter Astrophysics Group, California Institute of Technology
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
